column4: Hi all. I'm getting a lot of frozen UI elements (windows, buttons, icons, etc.). Things freeze sporadically starting immediately after I log in. Logging in to a new user fixes the problem temporarily, even on my old account. Does anyone know what the problem might be?
you may want to be doing a memtest to check that out.  and monitor dmesg output when it happens.
I did a memtest at boot, it came back fine. I've also done a badblocks test and it was fine. Booting from the LiveCD also works fine. I can do the memtest again if you think it will help.
a memtest for how long.. also alternative testing of various live cd's to see if the issue affects them. would point into it being either an OS issue..or a hardware issue.
whats your video chipset? the live cd  may be using differnt video drivers.
I selected memtest86+ at boot
for how long did you run it?
nvidia GTX 460 GPU. Custom drivers probably weren't installed on the LiveCD, but they are on the second user account where things are working.
I let the memtest run until it said it had completed.
probably took about 2 hours?
so a second user account works totally fine?

Yes, totally fine. What's more is that if I login to that account, logout, and login to my original account, everything is fine there. Until I suspend or restart. Then I have to do the process again to get it working.
if a 2nd user works totally fine that basically points it to being some odd user setting issue for the problem user.

I agree. But I have no clue what settings to look at or delete. I didn't change anything (besides updating my system). The problem exists on both Unity and GNOME 2, so I don't think it's Unity related. I don't know enough about the UI to know what to look for.
simple.. remove them all.... :)
unity and the 'classic' desktop are using the same underlaying stuff..
theres commands to totally reset compiz and unity.
I've done unity --reset and gconftool-2 --recursive-unset /apps/compiz-1
no effect.
how odd..  i guess you could go hardcore and clean out your entire home dir.. (move everything over to some subdir) and log out/back in...
Yeah, that may be what I end up doing. Frustrating, but feasible.
